title: Skill Gap Analysis
text:
6 üìã Personalized Recommendations
üßë‚Äçüíª Sundar‚Äôs Skill Gaps: Sundar demonstrates equally high skill gaps across three critical areas: Communication, Data Analysis, and Problem Solving, each with a score of 4. This suggests that while he may have strong foundational knowledge, there is significant room for development in both technical and soft skills. Improving his data analysis capabilities could enhance his decision-making, while strengthening communication and problem-solving will boost collaboration and efficiency in cross-functional roles.
üßë‚Äçüíª Krystie‚Äôs Skill Gaps :
Krystie‚Äôs top developmental areas are well-balanced and revolve around leadership-oriented tasks: Management, Presentations, and Project Management, all with a gap of 3. This points to a need for stronger execution and communication of strategic ideas. Enhancing her presentation skills, in particular, would enable her to convey ideas more convincingly, while project and team management improvements could increase her effectiveness as a future leader.
üßë‚Äçüíª Nakul‚Äôs Skill Gaps :
Nakul continues to show moderate gaps in Communication and Management (3 each), with a slightly lower gap in Leadership (2). These gaps indicate that his development should focus on articulating ideas clearly and overseeing teams or tasks more effectively. While his leadership gap is lower, refining how he influences and guides others could elevate his contributions in group settings.

Based on our analysis of job data from 2024:

AI-related jobs tend to offer significantly higher salaries across all industries, with the average salary in AI roles exceeding non-AI roles by over $45,000.
Industry choice matters ‚Äî Technology and Finance roles are high-paying, while roles in Marketing and Construction tend to offer lower compensation.
AI classification is highly predictable from just salary and industry, suggesting a clear separation in job types.
Clustering shows meaningful segmentation of roles, reinforcing that jobs naturally group into high-skill/high-pay and low-skill/low-pay categories.

Recommendations:

Job seekers looking to maximize salary potential should pivot toward AI-focused roles, especially in the Technology sector.
Candidates should consider upskilling with AI and data-related tools to stand out in the evolving market.
Non-AI professionals in lower-paying industries should consider geographic relocation, reskilling, or transitioning industries to remain competitive.

title: AI vs.¬†Non-AI Job Growth ‚Äì Is AI taking over or creating more jobs?
text:
Decoding the Job Market: AI vs.¬†Non-AI ‚Äì Disruption or Opportunity? As AI continues to reshape industries, I wanted to explore a question that hits close to home for many of us navigating the job hunt:
Is AI eliminating traditional jobs‚Äîor opening new doors for human talent?
üìå Why This Topic? Because stepping into the 2025 job market feels like walking into a battlefield‚Äîwhere AI seems to level up faster than the rest of us. So I decided to dive in and analyze the data behind the noise.
My key questions: ‚úÖ Is AI replacing or generating jobs? ‚úÖ How do AI vs.¬†Non-AI roles compare in growth and salaries? ‚úÖ What can job seekers do to stay competitive‚Äîespecially in an AI-dominated hiring process?
üë®‚Äçüíª Who Am I? A curious grad student & data enthusiast using Python, web analytics, and a whole lot of hustle to decode what‚Äôs really going on in the job market ( Also )
üöÄ Goal: Build a research-backed job strategy that helps real people (like us) thrive in a future shaped by AI.

title: AI vs.¬†Non-AI Careers: Job Growth and Market Trends in 2024
text:
Introduction
Artificial Intelligence (AI) is accelerating at an unprecedented pace, transforming the global employment landscape and fueling discussions around job displacement, wage differences, and the rise of new career paths. As automation powered by AI integrates into diverse sectors, the workforce is compelled to keep pace with shifting skill requirements. This report examines the rise and implications of AI-driven vs.¬†traditional careers in 2024, offering a detailed look at salary trends, job stability, industry shifts, and emerging professional opportunities.
Research Rationale
The impact of Artificial Intelligence (AI) on employment is both disruptive and generative‚Äîeliminating certain roles while simultaneously creating new ones. As highlighted by the World Economic Forum (2024), AI is projected to displace 85 million jobs by 2025, but also give rise to 97 million new opportunities. This profound transformation calls for a data-informed analysis to explore:
The distinctions between AI-powered roles and traditional job functions.
Industry-specific trends in AI-driven job creation vs.¬†displacement.
The most in-demand skills across both AI and Non-AI career paths.
Variations in salary patterns between emerging and conventional professions.
Through a combination of ‚Äúlightcast‚Äù labor data, collaborative GitHub workflows, and Quarto publishing, this study delivers actionable insights to guide job seekers navigating the 2024 workforce.
Literature Review
1. Emergence of New AI-Centric Job Titles
Brown ((2024)) highlights the rapid evolution of the job market, noting the creation of new AI-driven roles such as Prompt Engineers, AI Ethics Officers, and Automation Specialists. These positions, which didn‚Äôt exist a decade ago, reflect the shifting demands of a technology-driven workforce.
2. AI‚Äôs Influence on Employment Patterns
As observed by Smith ((2023)), sectors like finance, healthcare, and technology have benefited from a rise in AI-powered roles. In contrast, retail, customer service, and manufacturing are increasingly at risk due to automation, leading to potential job displacement.
3. Compensation Disparities Between AI and Traditional Roles
Johnson ((2024)) reports that roles in AI‚Äîsuch as Machine Learning Engineers and Data Scientists‚Äîcommand 30‚Äì50% higher salaries than traditional positions like Mechanical Engineers or Accountants. This pay premium is driven by demand for AI skills and the relative security these roles offer in an evolving job market.

title: AI vs.¬†Non-AI Careers: Job Growth and Market Trends in 2024

‚úÖ Finding: AI-based roles offer higher salaries and greater career stability than traditional jobs.

Career Strategy Recommendations
To stay competitive in an AI-transformed job market, professionals are encouraged to:
Build Expertise in AI & Data Science üìä
Develop technical proficiency in Python, Machine Learning, and AI-powered analytics.
Enroll in courses covering Natural Language Processing (NLP), Big Data, and model deployment techniques.
Focus on AI-Accelerated Industries üöÄ
Align your career path with sectors embracing AI at scale‚Äîparticularly finance, technology, and healthcare‚Äîwhere demand for AI talent is growing rapidly.
Adopt AI Tools in Everyday Workflows üí°

title: Exploratory Data Analysis on Job Postings

2 üìà Job Postings Over Time









Between May and September 2024, job postings remained relatively stable, averaging around 15,000 per month. A noticeable dip occurred in July, possibly reflecting a seasonal slowdown in hiring. Activity quickly rebounded in August and peaked slightly in September, indicating renewed demand in the job market.

title: Job Growth Trends & Strategy: A Comparative Look at AI and Non-AI Roles
text:
With the rapid evolution of AI, professionals must stay ahead by adopting future-ready strategies. This section outlines key approaches to sustaining career growth in an AI-driven job market.


1. Stay Updated with AI Regulations & Ethics
As AI adoption expands, professionals must remain informed about evolving policies, data privacy laws, and ethical automation practices.
Insights from organizations like the IEEE Standards Association and OpenAI Policy Institute help track regulatory developments and ethical frameworks.
Understanding AI bias mitigation and global compliance standards will be vital for businesses implementing AI at scale (ScienceDirect (2024)).
2. Optimize Resumes for ATS (Applicant Tracking Systems)
With over 75% of companies using AI-powered ATS systems, making resumes AI-friendly is more important than ever.
Focus on formatting for machine readability, using role-specific keywords, and avoiding over-designed templates.
Tools like Jobscan and Resume Worded can help optimize your resume for higher visibility before submission (Massachusetts (2024)).
3. Adapt to Hybrid Work Environments
As AI reshapes remote and hybrid workflows, digital collaboration skills are now essential.
Proficiency in tools like Slack, Zoom, and AI-integrated platforms such as Asana or Trello supports seamless hybrid operations.
Leveraging AI-assisted scheduling and workflow automation increases both productivity and adaptability in flexible work settings (Forum (2024)).
4. Upskill in AI & Data Science
The growing impact of AI across sectors demands expertise in machine learning, automation, and ethical AI deployment.
Take advantage of programs like Google‚Äôs AI & ML certification, IBM‚Äôs AI Engineering course, or platforms like Udacity and LinkedIn Learning.
Gaining hands-on experience with Python, TensorFlow, and AutoML will enhance your edge in a competitive AI-driven job market (Forbes (2024)).
5. Strengthen Human Skills
Despite AI advancements, skills like emotional intelligence, creativity, and critical thinking remain highly valued.
Employers in AI-led industries prioritize leadership, problem-solving, and adaptability.
Workshops, mentorships, and innovation bootcamps help sharpen these timeless competencies (BizReport (2024)).
6. Leverage Networking & Industry Connections
A significant 70%+ of job opportunities come through networking‚Äînot job boards.
Build industry connections via AI-specific LinkedIn communities, forums, and live events like the Google AI Summit or MIT AI Research Meetups.
Participating in hackathons and conferences fosters knowledge sharing and expands access to emerging roles (Online (2024)).



‚Ä¶..Aspect‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ ||‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶AI-Driven Careers‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶..||‚Ä¶..Traditional Careers‚Ä¶.. Employment Outlook || Rapid expansion (97M jobs projected) || Steady but slower growth Skill Set || Emphasis on AI, ML, and Data Science || Focus on domain-specific expertise Compensation Trends || Elevated income potential || Consistent and stable pay Job Stability || Demands ongoing skill upgrades || Generally more secure roles Work Setting || Predominantly hybrid or remote || Primarily in-person work Dominant Sectors || Technology, Finance, Healthcare || Manufacturing, Retail

title: Job Growth Trends & Strategy: A Comparative Look at AI and Non-AI Roles
text:
1. Stay Updated with AI Regulations & Ethics
As AI adoption expands, professionals must remain informed about evolving policies, data privacy laws, and ethical automation practices.
Insights from organizations like the IEEE Standards Association and OpenAI Policy Institute help track regulatory developments and ethical frameworks.
Understanding AI bias mitigation and global compliance standards will be vital for businesses implementing AI at scale (ScienceDirect (2024)).
2. Optimize Resumes for ATS (Applicant Tracking Systems)
With over 75% of companies using AI-powered ATS systems, making resumes AI-friendly is more important than ever.
Focus on formatting for machine readability, using role-specific keywords, and avoiding over-designed templates.
Tools like Jobscan and Resume Worded can help optimize your resume for higher visibility before submission (Massachusetts (2024)).
3. Adapt to Hybrid Work Environments
As AI reshapes remote and hybrid workflows, digital collaboration skills are now essential.
Proficiency in tools like Slack, Zoom, and AI-integrated platforms such as Asana or Trello supports seamless hybrid operations.
Leveraging AI-assisted scheduling and workflow automation increases both productivity and adaptability in flexible work settings (Forum (2024)).
4. Upskill in AI & Data Science
The growing impact of AI across sectors demands expertise in machine learning, automation, and ethical AI deployment.
Take advantage of programs like Google‚Äôs AI & ML certification, IBM‚Äôs AI Engineering course, or platforms like Udacity and LinkedIn Learning.
Gaining hands-on experience with Python, TensorFlow, and AutoML will enhance your edge in a competitive AI-driven job market (Forbes (2024)).
5. Strengthen Human Skills
Despite AI advancements, skills like emotional intelligence, creativity, and critical thinking remain highly valued.
Employers in AI-led industries prioritize leadership, problem-solving, and adaptability.
Workshops, mentorships, and innovation bootcamps help sharpen these timeless competencies (BizReport (2024)).
6. Leverage Networking & Industry Connections
A significant 70%+ of job opportunities come through networking‚Äînot job boards.
Build industry connections via AI-specific LinkedIn communities, forums, and live events like the Google AI Summit or MIT AI Research Meetups.
Participating in hackathons and conferences fosters knowledge sharing and expands access to emerging roles (Online (2024)).

title: Job Growth Trends & Strategy: A Comparative Look at AI and Non-AI Roles

title: Job Growth Trends & Strategy: A Comparative Look at AI and Non-AI Roles
text:
title: ‚ÄúAI vs.¬†Non-AI Job Growth: Is AI Taking Over or Creating More Jobs?‚Äù author: - ‚ÄúSundarajan Swaminathan‚Äù date: ‚Äú2025-02-18‚Äù format: html bibliography: references.bib csl: csl/econometrica.csl toc: true execute: echo: true ‚Äî
üåê Introduction: AI and the Future of Work
The rapid evolution of Artificial Intelligence (AI) is revolutionizing the global workforce‚Äîraising one big question: üîç Is AI stealing jobs, or is it opening doors to entirely new careers?
As AI systems become more integrated into day-to-day operations‚Äîfrom automation in factories to algorithmic decision-making in finance‚Äîthe debate over job displacement versus job creation has intensified. This report investigates both sides of the AI impact equation:
The risk of automation replacing traditional roles
The emergence of high-growth, AI-powered careers
In this pivotal moment, professionals across all industries must rethink their capabilities, stay agile with technological adoption, and proactively future-proof their skillsets.
üéØ Why This Study Matters in 2025
The fusion of AI and employment isn‚Äôt just a tech topic‚Äîit‚Äôs a global economic and societal concern. As of 2025, this intersection directly affects:
‚úÖ Employees ‚Äì Needing to continuously reskill and embrace lifelong learning ‚úÖ Employers ‚Äì Balancing automation with human capital strategies ‚úÖ Governments ‚Äì Designing policy to safeguard and reskill displaced workers ‚úÖ Students & Career Changers ‚Äì Navigating toward sustainable, future-proof roles
üî• Core Questions Explored:
Which jobs are most vulnerable to automation?
What industries are booming due to AI?
Do AI-powered roles offer higher pay and better growth?
What actions must professionals take to remain relevant?

title: Job Growth Trends & Strategy: A Comparative Look at AI and Non-AI Roles
section: 0.1 These aren‚Äôt hypothetical questions‚Äîthey are urgent priorities for a workforce navigating transformation.
text:
0.1 These aren‚Äôt hypothetical questions‚Äîthey are urgent priorities for a workforce navigating transformation.
ü§ñ AI: Job Disruptor and Creator
AI‚Äôs influence on employment is twofold‚Äîit both replaces and generates jobs.
According to the World Economic Forum (2024):
üîÅ 85 million jobs will be displaced by AI by 2025 ‚ûï But 97 million new roles will be created, many of which didn‚Äôt exist a decade ago
‚ö†Ô∏è Roles Most at Risk: üßæ Administrative & Clerical ‚Äì Data entry clerks, receptionists
üõçÔ∏è Retail & Banking ‚Äì Cashiers, loan officers, bank tellers
üè≠ Manufacturing ‚Äì Machine operators, assembly line staff
üöÄ Emerging AI-Powered Roles:
üß† AI/ML Engineers ‚Äì Developing intelligent algorithms
üìä Data Scientists & Algorithmic Traders ‚Äì Deriving insights and driving automated decision-making
üé® AI-Enhanced Creatives ‚Äì Using AI tools for design, copywriting, and content generation
‚öñÔ∏è AI Ethics & Policy Analysts ‚Äì Addressing ethical use and regulation of AI

title: Job Growth Trends & Strategy: A Comparative Look at AI and Non-AI Roles
section: 0.2 As AI transforms industries, digital literacy, analytical skills, and creativity will be more important than ever.
text:
0.2 As AI transforms industries, digital literacy, analytical skills, and creativity will be more important than ever.
Report Structure: What You‚Äôll Learn
This study is structured into three practical sections designed for job seekers, professionals, educators, and policymakers:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Findings ‚Äì Understanding the Job Shift Breakdown of job losses vs.¬†creation across major sectors
AI‚Äôs impact on finance, healthcare, manufacturing, and retail
Comparison of salary trends in AI and Non-AI roles
‚û°Ô∏è Read the findings - (findings.qmd)
2Ô∏è‚É£ Strategy ‚Äì Adapting to the AI Economy Top AI skills in demand for 2024 and beyond
Sectors with highest AI job creation potential
Concrete career strategies to thrive amidst automation
‚û°Ô∏è Explore recommendations - (career_strategy.qmd)

Conclusion: Navigating the AI-Powered Job Market
AI isn‚Äôt just disrupting the world of work‚Äîit‚Äôs reshaping it. This transformation brings both uncertainty and opportunity.
üîé Key Takeaways:
AI will not eliminate human work‚Äîit will redefine it Upskilling and adaptability are the ultimate career insurance AI should be seen as a partner in productivity, not just a disruptor The future of work belongs to those who are prepared, proactive, and AI-aware.
üìà Let‚Äôs move from fear to foresight‚Äîand embrace the new world of AI-powered careers.

title: ‚ÄúFindings ‚Äì AI‚Äôs Impact on Job Growth‚Äù bibliography: references.bib csl: csl/econometrica.csl toc: true format: html: code-fold: true df-print: paged jupyter: python3 execute: echo: true ‚Äî

title: Job Growth Trends & Strategy: A Comparative Look at AI and Non-AI Roles
section: 1.3 1Ô∏è‚É£ The State of AI-Powered Job Growth
text:
1.3 1Ô∏è‚É£ The State of AI-Powered Job Growth

1.3.1 1.1 AI‚Äôs Impact on Different Industries
Artificial Intelligence (AI) is reshaping industries, leading to both job displacement and job creation. According to the World Economic Forum (2024), AI will impact 85 million jobs but simultaneously create 97 million new ones (Forum (2024)).


1.3.2 üìä Interactive Bar Chart: AI Job Impact by Industry


Code
import pandas as pd
import plotly.express as px

# Industry-wise job impact data
data = {
    "Industry": ["Tech & Data Science", "Finance", "Manufacturing", "Retail & Customer Service", "Healthcare", "Marketing & Advertising"],
    "Jobs Created": [500000, 300000, 250000, 200000, 400000, 150000],
    "Jobs Lost": [50000, 150000, 300000, 500000, 50000, 80000]
}

df = pd.DataFrame(data)

# Create interactive bar chart
fig = px.bar(
    df,
    x="Industry",
    y=["Jobs Created", "Jobs Lost"],
    barmode="group",
    title="<b>AI‚Äôs Impact on Job Growth vs. Loss by Industry</b>",
    labels={
        "Industry": "<i>Industry</i>",
        "value": "<i>Number of Jobs</i>",
        "variable": "<i>Job Impact</i>"
    },
    color_discrete_sequence=px.colors.qualitative.Bold
)

fig.update_layout(
    font=dict(family="Arial", size=14),
    title_font_size=20,
    plot_bgcolor="rgba(240,240,240,0.9)",
    paper_bgcolor="rgba(240,240,240,0.95)",
    legend_title_text="<b>Job Category</b>",
    xaxis=dict(showgrid=False),
    yaxis=dict(showgrid=True, gridcolor="lightgrey", zeroline=False)
)

fig.update_traces(marker_line_width=1.5, marker_line_color='black')

fig.show()


        
        
        


                            
                                            


‚úÖ Finding: AI is not just eliminating jobs‚Äîit is reshaping job roles and requiring new skill sets (Online (2024)).

title: Job Growth Trends & Strategy: A Comparative Look at AI and Non-AI Roles
text:
1.4 2Ô∏è‚É£ AI vs.¬†Non-AI Career Salary Trends
As AI becomes more integrated into industries, AI-powered careers offer significantly higher salaries than traditional jobs (BizReport (2024)). Below is a comparison of AI vs.¬†Non-AI salaries in 2024.

1.4.1 üìà Interactive Table: AI vs.¬†Non-AI Job Salaries


Code
import plotly.graph_objects as go
import pandas as pd

# Salary comparison data
df_salary = pd.DataFrame({
    "Job Role": ["Machine Learning Engineer", "Data Scientist", "AI Risk Analyst (Finance)", "Software Developer", "Mechanical Engineer", "Customer Service Rep"],
    "AI-Powered Career?": ["‚úÖ Yes", "‚úÖ Yes", "‚úÖ Yes", "‚ùå No", "‚ùå No", "‚ùå No"],
    "Average Salary (2024)": ["$140,000", "$125,000", "$118,000", "$95,000", "$85,000", "$45,000"]
})

fig = go.Figure(data=[go.Table(
    header=dict(values=list(df_salary.columns),
                fill_color='paleturquoise',
                align='left'),
    cells=dict(values=[df_salary[col] for col in df_salary.columns],
               fill_color='lavender',
               align='left'))
])

fig.show()


                            
                                            


‚úÖ Finding: AI-powered careers command higher salaries than traditional roles, making AI skills essential for career advancement (Forbes (2024)).

title: Job Growth Trends & Strategy: A Comparative Look at AI and Non-AI Roles
section: 1.5 3Ô∏è‚É£ AI Job Automation Risks: Who Is at Risk?
text:
1.5 3Ô∏è‚É£ AI Job Automation Risks: Who Is at Risk?
AI is automating repetitive tasks across industries, putting millions of jobs at risk. Research from ScienceDirect (2024) shows that AI will impact several sectors over the next five years (ScienceDirect (2024)).







At-Risk Job Categories
Examples of Jobs AI is Replacing




Clerical Work
Data entry clerks, secretaries


Retail & Banking
Cashiers, bank tellers, call center agents


Manufacturing & Logistics
Assembly line workers, warehouse packers



‚úÖ Finding: The job displacement risk is highest for repetitive, rule-based tasks‚Äîbut AI-driven reskilling can mitigate this risk (Massachusetts (2024)).

title: Job Growth Trends & Strategy: A Comparative Look at AI and Non-AI Roles
text:

title: Findings ‚Äì AI‚Äôs Impact on Job Growth
text:
Artificial Intelligence (AI) is reshaping industries, leading to both job displacement and job creation. According to the World Economic Forum (2024), AI will impact 85 million jobs but simultaneously create 97 million new ones (Forum (2024)).





Code
import pandas as pd
import plotly.express as px

# Industry-wise job impact data
data = {
    "Industry": ["Tech & Data Science", "Finance", "Manufacturing", "Retail & Customer Service", "Healthcare", "Marketing & Advertising"],
    "Jobs Created": [500000, 300000, 250000, 200000, 400000, 150000],
    "Jobs Lost": [50000, 150000, 300000, 500000, 50000, 80000]
}

df = pd.DataFrame(data)

# Create interactive bar chart
fig = px.bar(
    df,
    x="Industry",
    y=["Jobs Created", "Jobs Lost"],
    barmode="group",
    title="<b>AI‚Äôs Impact on Job Growth vs. Loss by Industry</b>",
    labels={
        "Industry": "<i>Industry</i>",
        "value": "<i>Number of Jobs</i>",
        "variable": "<i>Job Impact</i>"
    },
    color_discrete_sequence=px.colors.qualitative.Bold
)

fig.update_layout(
    font=dict(family="Arial", size=14),
    title_font_size=20,
    plot_bgcolor="rgba(240,240,240,0.9)",
    paper_bgcolor="rgba(240,240,240,0.95)",
    legend_title_text="<b>Job Category</b>",
    xaxis=dict(showgrid=False),
    yaxis=dict(showgrid=True, gridcolor="lightgrey", zeroline=False)
)

fig.update_traces(marker_line_width=1.5, marker_line_color='black')

fig.show()


        
        
        


                            
                                            


‚úÖ Finding: AI is not just eliminating jobs‚Äîit is reshaping job roles and requiring new skill sets (Online (2024)).
